item.title: Havi add a quote by Theodor Adorno
item.description: "Behind every work of art lies an uncommitted crime" -- Theodor Adorno

item.title: Havi add a quote by Emmanuel Levinas
item.description: "Politics is opposed to morality, as philosophy to naïveté." -- Emmanuel Levinas

item.title: Havi add a quote by Marshall McLuhan
item.description: "I don't necessarily agree with everything that I say." -- Marshall McLuhan

item.title: Havi add a quote by Marshall McLuhan
item.description: "The medium is the message." -- Marshall McLuhan

item.title: Havi add a quote by Margaret Atwood
item.description: "Don't let the bastards grind you down." -- Margaret Atwood

item.title: Havi add a quote by Margaret Atwood
item.description: "War is what happens when language fails." -- Margaret Atwood

item.title: Havi add a quote by Margaret Atwood
item.description: "If you knew what was going to happen, if you knew everything that was going to happen next—if you knew in advance the consequences of your own actions—you'd be doomed. You'd be ruined as God. You'd be a stone. You'd never eat or drink or laugh or get out of bed in the morning. You'd never love anyone, ever again. You'd never dare to." -- Margaret Atwood

item.title: Havi add a quote by Don DeLillo
item.description: "I don’t want your candor. I want your soul in a silver thimble." -- Don DeLillo

item.title: Havi add a quote by Don DeLillo
item.description: "He said, "The word for moonlight is moonlight." -- Don DeLillo

item.title: Havi add a quote by Don DeLillo
item.description: "There are dead stars that still shine because their light is trapped in time. Where do I stand in this light, which does not strictly exist?" -- Don DeLillo

item.title: Havi add a quote by Don Delillo
item.description: "He wanted paper and something to write with, some way to sustain a thought, to place it in the world." -- Don Delillo

item.title: Havi add a quote by Don DeLillo
item.description: "He took pains to avoid self-depreciation, self-mockery, ambiguity, irony, subtlety, vulnerability, a civilized world-weariness and a tragic sense of history--the very things, he says, that are most natural to him." -- Don DeLillo

item.title: Havi add a quote by Joss Whedon
item.description: "Remember to always be yourself. Unless you suck." -- Joss Whedon

item.title: Havi add a quote by Marti Noxon, Buffy the Vampire Slayer
item.description: "Spike (to Giles) : Oh, poor Watcher. Did your life pass before your eyes — 'Cuppa tea, cuppa tea... almost got shagged... cuppa tea'?" -- Marti Noxon, Buffy the Vampire Slayer

item.title: Havi add a quote by Joss Whedon
item.description: "If you're going to make a science fiction movie, then have a hover craft chase, for God's sake." -- Joss Whedon

item.title: Havi add a quote by Joss Whedon
item.description: "I'll take crazy over stupid any day." -- Joss Whedon

item.title: Havi add a quote by Joss Whedon
item.description: "Recognizing power in another does not diminish your own." -- Joss Whedon

item.title: Havi add a quote by Joss Whedon
item.description: "Very occasionally, if you pay really close attention, life doesn't suck." -- Joss Whedon

item.title: Havi add a quote by joss whedon
item.description: "I cannot abide useless people." -- joss whedon

item.title: Havi add a quote by Joss Whedon
item.description: "Humor keeps us alive. Humor and food. Don't forget food. You can go a week without laughing." -- Joss Whedon

item.title: Havi add a quote by Karl Marx
item.description:
"The foundation of irreligious criticism is: Man makes religion, religion does not make man. Religion is, indeed, the self-consciousness and self-esteem of man who has either not yet won through to himself, or has already lost himself again. But man is no abstract being squatting outside the world. Man is the world of man – state, society. This state and this society produce religion, which is an inverted consciousness of the world, because they are an inverted world...
Religious suffering is, at one and the same time, the expression of real suffering and a protest against real suffering. Religion is the sigh of the oppressed creature, the heart of a heartless world, and the soul of soulless conditions. It is the opium of the people.
The abolition of religion as the illusory happiness of the people is the demand for their real happiness. To call on them to give up their illusions about their condition is to call on them to give up a condition that requires illusions. The criticism of religion is, therefore, in embryo, the criticism of that vale of tears of which religion is the halo.
Criticism has plucked the imaginary flowers on the chain not in order that man shall continue to bear that chain without fantasy or consolation, but so that he shall throw off the chain and pluck the living flower. The criticism of religion disillusions man, so that he will think, act, and fashion his reality like a man who has discarded his illusions and regained his senses, so that he will move around himself as his own true Sun. Religion is only the illusory Sun which revolves around man as long as he does not revolve around himself." -- Karl Marx

item.title: Havi add a quote by Karl Marx
item.description: "[author:Hegel|6188] remarks somewhere that all great, world-historical facts and personages occur, as it were, twice. He has forgotten to add: the first time as tragedy, the second as farce." -- Karl Marx

item.title: Havi add a quote by Karl Marx
item.description: "The oppressed are allowed once every few years to decide which particular representatives of the oppressing class are to represent and repress them." -- Karl Marx

item.title: Havi add a quote by Simone de Beauvoir
item.description: "What an odd thing a diary is: the things you omit are more important than those you put in." -- Simone de Beauvoir

item.title: Havi add a quote by Simone de Beauvoir
item.description: "She was ready to deny the existence of space and time rather than admit that love might not be eternal." -- Simone de Beauvoir

item.title: Havi add a quote by Jean-Paul Sartre
item.description: "Man is condemned to be free; because once thrown into the world, he is responsible for everything he does. It is up to you to give [life] a meaning." -- Jean-Paul Sartre

item.title: Havi add a quote by Jean-Paul Sartre
item.description: "If you're lonely when you're alone, you're in bad company." -- Jean-Paul Sartre

item.title: Havi add a quote by Jean-Paul Sartre
item.description: "Words are loaded pistols." -- Jean-Paul Sartre

item.title: Havi add a quote by Jean-Paul Sartre
item.description: "Ha! to forget. How childish! I feel you in my bones. Your silence screams in my ears. You may nail your mouth shut, you may cut out your tongue, can you keep yourself from existing? Will you stop your thoughts." -- Jean-Paul Sartre

item.title: Havi add a quote by Jean-Paul Sartre
item.description: "I suppose it is out of laziness that the world is the same day after day. Today it seemed to want to change. And then anything, anything could happen." -- Jean-Paul Sartre
